maml:description.maml:para: Starts an interactive SSH session to an Azure Resource (such as Azure VMs or Arc Servers). Users can login using AAD accounts, or local user accounts via standard SSH authentication. Use AAD account login for the best security and convenience.

Start interactive SSH session to an Azure Resource (currently supports Azure VMs and Arc Servers). Users can login using AAD issued certificates or using local user credentials. We recommend login using AAD issued certificates when possible. Important note: When connecting to Azure Arc resources, this cmdlet requires the Az.Ssh.ArcProxy module to also be installed in the client machine. The cmdlet will attempt to install the module from the PowerShell Gallery, but the user also has the option to install it themselves. It is important that the user also has permission to execute the Proxy files in the Az.Ssh.ArcProxy module, or the connection will fail. You can find the Az.Ssh.ArcServer module in the PowerShell Gallery: https://aka.ms/PowerShellGallery-Az.Ssh.ArcProxy.
SSH Certificate to be used to authenticate to local user account.
The credentials, account, tenant, and subscription used for communication with Azure.

When connecting to Arc resources, do not prompt for confirmation before updating the allowed port for SSH connection in the Connection Endpoint to match the target port or to install Az.Ssh.ArcProxy module from the PowerShell Gallery, if needed.
IP Address of target Azure VM.
Username for a local user in the target resource.
Returns true if connection is successful.
Port to connect to on the remote host.
Path to private key file.
Path to public key file.
Start a RDP connection over SSH connection. Only supported on Windows OS.
Additional SSH arguments passed to OpenSSH.
SSH Certificate to be used to authenticate to local user account.
The credentials, account, tenant, and subscription used for communication with Azure.

When connecting to Arc resources, do not prompt for confirmation before updating the allowed port for SSH connection in the Connection Endpoint to match the target port or to install Az.Ssh.ArcProxy module from the PowerShell Gallery, if needed.

Port to connect to on the remote host.
Path to private key file.
Path to public key file.
Start a RDP connection over SSH connection. Only supported on Windows OS.
Resource group name.
Resource type of the target resource.
Additional SSH arguments passed to OpenSSH.
When connecting to an Azure VM, this flag specifies that it should connect to one of the private IPs of the VM. It requires connectivity to the private IP.
SSH Certificate to be used to authenticate to local user account.

When connecting to Arc resources, do not prompt for confirmation before updating the allowed port for SSH connection in the Connection Endpoint to match the target port or to install Az.Ssh.ArcProxy module from the PowerShell Gallery, if needed.

maml:description.maml:para: This cmdlet exports an SSH configuration file that can be used to connect to Azure Resources through client applications that support OpenSSH config and certificates. SSH config files can be created that use AAD issued certificates or local user credentials.

The exported SSH configuration file can be used to connect to Azure Resources by client applications that support OpenSSH config and certificates. Applications such as git and rsync can use configuration file by setting the command to 'ssh -F /path/to/config'. For example: rsync -e 'ssh -F /path/to/config'. Users can create ssh config files that use AAD issued certificates or local user credentials. Important note: When connecting to Azure Arc resources, this cmdlet requires the Az.Ssh.ArcProxy module to also be installed in the client machine. The cmdlet will attempt to install the module from the PowerShell Gallery, but the user also has the option to install it themselves. It is important that the user also has permission to execute the Proxy files in the Az.Ssh.ArcProxy module, or the connection will fail. You can find the Az.Ssh.ArcServer module in the PowerShell Gallery: https://aka.ms/PowerShellGallery-Az.Ssh.ArcProxy.
SSH Certificate to be used to authenticate to local user account.
Path to write SSH configuration to.
The credentials, account, tenant, and subscription used for communication with Azure.

When connecting to Arc resources, do not prompt for confirmation before updating the allowed port for SSH connection in the Connection Endpoint to match the target port or to install Az.Ssh.ArcProxy module from the PowerShell Gallery, if needed.
IP Address of target Azure VM.
Directory where generated keys and certificates will be stored.
Username for a local user in the target resource.
Overwrite the config file, instead of appending new entry to the end of the file.
Port to connect to on the remote host.
Path to private key file.
Path to public key file.
SSH Certificate to be used to authenticate to local user account.
Path to write SSH configuration to.

command:example.maml:title: Example 1: Export a SSH configuration file for connecting to a resource using AAD issued certificates for authentication.

dev:remarks.maml:para: When a -LocalUser is not supplied, the cmdlet will attempt to create a certificate to login using Azure AD. This is currently only supported for resources running Linux OS. When using Azure AD to login to resource, the Host name in the configuration entry will be "{resource group name}-{resource name}", or "{ip address}" for Azure VMs.

command:example.maml:title: Example 2: Export a SSH configuration file for connecting to the Public Ip of an Azure Virtual Machine using AAD issued certificates.
Example 3: Export a SSH configuration file for connecting to Local User on Azure Resource using SSH certificates for authentication

dev:remarks.maml:para: When using local user credentials to login, the host name in the configuration entry will be "{resource group name}-{resource name}-{username}", or "{ip address}-{username}" for Azure VMs.

command:example.maml:title: Example 4: Export a SSH configuration file for connecting to Local User on Azure Resource using SSH private key for authentication
Example 5: Export a SSH configuration file for connecting to Local User on Azure Resource using interactive username and password for authentication
Example 6: Determine where generated keys and certificates for the certificate will the stored.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Generated keys and certificates are, by default, stored in "az_ssh_config" directory in the same directory as the config file. The -KeysDestinationFolder parameter allows user to decide where the keys will be stored.

command:example.maml:title: Example 7: Create a generic config for use with any Azure VM.
----- Example 8: Provide the Resource Type of the target. -----

dev:remarks.maml:para: This parameter is useful when there is more than one supported resource with the same name in the Resource Group.
